Chat with an OpenAI model

Source: R/provider-openai.R
chat_openai.Rd

OpenAI provides a number of chat-based models, mostly under the ChatGPT brand. Note that a ChatGPT Plus membership does not grant access to the API. You will need to sign up for a developer account (and pay for it) at the developer platform.

For authentication, we recommend saving your API key to the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable in your .Renviron file. You can easily edit this file by calling usethis::edit_r_environ().

Usage

chat_openai(
  system_prompt = NULL,
  turns = NULL,
  base_url = "https://api.openai.com/v1",
  api_key = openai_key(),
  model = NULL,
  seed = NULL,
  api_args = list(),
  echo = c("none", "text", "all")
)

Arguments

system_prompt

A system prompt to set the behavior of the assistant.

turns

A list of Turns to start the chat with (i.e., continuing a previous conversation). If not provided, the conversation begins from scratch.

base_url

The base URL to the endpoint; the default uses OpenAI.

api_key

The API key to use for authentication. You generally should not supply this directly, but instead set the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable.

model

The model to use for the chat. The default, NULL, will pick a reasonable default, and tell you about. We strongly recommend explicitly choosing a model for all but the most casual use.

seed

Optional integer seed that ChatGPT uses to try and make output more reproducible.

api_args

Named list of arbitrary extra arguments appended to the body of every chat API call.

echo

One of the following options:

  • none: don't emit any output (default when running in a function).

  • text: echo text output as it streams in (default when running at the console).

  • all: echo all input and output.

Note this only affects the chat() method.

Value

A Chat object.

See also

Other chatbots: chat_bedrock(), chat_claude(), chat_cortex_analyst(), chat_databricks(), chat_deepseek(), chat_gemini(), chat_github(), chat_groq(), chat_ollama(), chat_openrouter(), chat_perplexity()

Examples

chat <- chat_openai()
#> Using model = "gpt-4o".
chat$chat("
  What is the difference between a tibble and a data frame?
  Answer with a bulleted list
")
#> - **Part of:** 
#>   - Data Frame: Base R package.
#>   - Tibble: Part of the `tibble` package (originally in the `dplyr` 
#> package).
#> 
#> - **Printing:**
#>   - Data Frame: Prints the entire dataset, which can be overwhelming 
#> for large datasets.
#>   - Tibble: Displays only the first few rows and columns, making it 
#> more manageable and readable. It also shows the type underneath the 
#> column names.
#> 
#> - **Subsetting:**
#>   - Data Frame: Subsetting can lead to unintended results, like 
#> dropping dimensions.
#>   - Tibble: Always returns a tibble, preserving dimensions with more 
#> consistent behavior.
#> 
#> - **Type Consistency:**
#>   - Data Frame: Can have inconsistent behavior around data types, 
#> sometimes converting strings to factors by default.
#>   - Tibble: Never converts strings to factors, preserving the type. It
#> is stricter in maintaining data types.
#> 
#> - **Column Access:**
#>   - Data Frame: Allows partial matching when accessing columns via the
#> `$` operator, which can lead to unintended columns being accessed.
#>   - Tibble: Requires exact matching for column access with the `$` 
#> operator.
#> 
#> - **Performance:**
#>   - Data Frame: Generally suitable for smaller datasets; performance 
#> can degrade with very large datasets.
#>   - Tibble: More optimized for performance with large datasets, 
#> particularly in tidyverse operations.
#> 
#> - **Flexibility:**
#>   - Data Frame: More flexible as it is deeply integrated with base R 
#> functions.
#>   - Tibble: Works seamlessly with tidyverse functions, offering better
#> integration with packages like `dplyr` and `ggplot2`.
#> 
#> - **Column Naming:**
#>   - Data Frame: Can have names that are not syntactic (e.g., spaces).
#>   - Tibble: Allows non-syntactic names but facilitates handling them 
#> with the use of backticks or `janitor` functions.
#> 
#> - **Legacy:**
#>   - Data Frame: Widely used in legacy code due to its presence since 
#> the early versions of R.
#>   - Tibble: Preferred in modern R programming, especially within the 
#> tidyverse ecosystem.

chat$chat("Tell me three funny jokes about statistcians")
#> Sure, here are three jokes about statisticians:
#> 
#> 1. **The Lost Umbrella:**
#>    - Why do statisticians love trampolines?
#>    - Because they like bouncing ideas around and getting some good 
#> range!
#> 
#> 2. **The Random Statistician:**
#>    - How do you know a statistician is trying to get romantic?
#>    - They whisper sweet nothings but always in terms of confidence 
#> intervals.
#> 
#> 3. **The Job Interview:**
#>    - Why did the statistician take a job at the bakery?
#>    - Because she was known for her excellent pie charts!
